None, 'body': "Sometimes there is some machine-level state that needs to be established before a pulumi program can run, for instance standing up an SSH tunnel or running a tool like `teleport` to connect to a kubernetes cluster. In order for any resource operations to succeed, this tool needs to run in advance of the program and ideally have a cleanup step run at the end. For instance it would be great to codify:

```console
$ tsh login --proxy=foo.bar.com
$ pulumi up --skip-preview
$ tsh logout
```

We need the same workflow to run even in `pulumi refresh` where the program is not run:

```console
$ tsh login --proxy=foo.bar.com
$ pulumi refresh --skip-preview
$ tsh logout
```

If this setup/cleanup is codified as a part of the pulumi program (or potentially stack/project) then users can avoid having to wrap `pulumi up` in shell scripts, or readmes/wikis that document the necessary set of steps/commands to successfully update a stack


[Command](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/command/) does not track any state other than command STDOUT, and doesn't really fit into this workflow (commands don't run on refresh either which is a requirement here).

## Issue details

A Pulumi organization main page shows a graph over time as an indicative measure of how many resources are present in the said organization. However, the resource count is global and there's no direct way to get the resource count via an API. Furthermore, there's no way to have detailed information on the resource types and attributes.

While it's possible to iterate through all the projects, stack and resource count for each stack, this is an inefficient method of extracting this information. For this to work *correctly*, the user making the calls need to have visibility on all projects and all stacks with this organization, otherwise the count may be missing some resources.

## Feature details

1.
